revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0.9.5
revision.text:
{{Short description|Rwandan journalist}} {{Infobox person | name = Kantano Habimana | image = Kantano Habimana.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 20th century | death_date = circa. 1998–2002{{cite news |title=CONVICTED ITALO-BELGIAN "HATE-RADIO" PRESENTER BEGINS TESTIMONY |author=FH |url=http://www.hirondellenews.com/ictr-rwanda/377-trials-ended/media-trial/18871-en-en-convicted-italo-belgian-qhate-radioq-presenter-begins-testimony79227922 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423020748/http://www.hirondellenews.com/ictr-rwanda/377-trials-ended/media-trial/18871-en-en-convicted-italo-belgian-qhate-radioq-presenter-begins-testimony79227922 |url-status=dead |archive-date=23 April 2014 |newspaper=Hirondelle News Agency |date=27 February 2002 |access-date=5 July 2020}} | death_place = [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] | known_for = Broadcasting hate propaganda on [[RTLM|Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines]] before and during the [[Rwandan genocide]] }} '''Kantano Habimana''' (died c. 1998–2002), commonly [[Mononym|referred to]] as '''Kantano''', was a presenter (''animateur'') on the Rwandan radio station [[RTLM]], which played a significant role in promoting the [[Rwandan genocide|genocide against the Tutsi]]. Like the station's [[RTLM#Individuals associated with the station|other broadcasters]], Habimana incited violence against [[Tutsi]] and moderate [[Hutu]] on the air.The Prosecutor v. Ferdinand Nahimana, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, Hassan Ngeze (Judgement and Sentence), ICTR-99-52-T, International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), 3 December 2003, available at: http://www.refworld.org/docid/404468bc2.html [accessed 21 December 2017] The most popular RTML ''animateur'' in terms of airtime, his appeal was attributed to his "loose and comical style on the air".{{Cite journal|last=Gulseth|first=Hege Løvdal|title=The Use of Propaganda in the Rwandan Genocide|url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/30834489.pdf|journal=[[University of Oslo]]|pages=56–57}} During his time on air, he was noted for his charisma and sense of humor, and he was noted for being able to speak profusely "as if people were right in front of him, which was good for getting their attention.{{Cite journal|last=Darryl|first=Li|title=Echoes of Violence: Considerations on Radio and Genocide in Rwanda|url=https://anthropology.uchicago.edu/sites/anthropology.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/echoes%20of%20violence%20-%20JGR%20final.pdf|journal=Journal of Genocide Research|volume=(2004), 6(1)|pages=17–20|archive-date=2021-06-20|access-date=2021-04-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210620044527/https://anthropology.uchicago.edu/sites/anthropology.uchicago.edu/files/uploads/echoes%20of%20violence%20-%20JGR%20final.pdf|url-status=dead}} == Early life == Habimana's birth date and most details about his early life prior to joining the RTLM are unknown. What is known is that he received a [[master's degree]] while studying [[journalism]] in [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] (now ''Saint Petersburg'') in the [[Soviet Union]] and subsequently worked at Rwandan newspapers ''Imvaho'' and ''Umurwanashyaka''. == Biography == Habimana is often named as both the most popular{{cite book |editor-last=Thompson |editor-first=Allan |title=The Media and the Rwanda Genocide |url=http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |access-date=19 March 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Pluto Press, Fountain Publishers, IDRC |isbn=978-0-74532-625-2 |page=98 |archive-date=16 September 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130916062855/http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |url-status=dead }} ''animateur'' of RTLM and the ''animateur'' with by far the most airtime, with his segments having accounted for approximately 33% of the station’s broadcast content.{{cite book |editor-last=Thompson |editor-first=Allan |title=Kimani, Mary: RTLM: the Medium that Became a Tool for Mass Murder. In "The Media and the Rwanda Genocide" |url=http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |access-date=19 March 2013 |year=2007 |publisher=Pluto Press, Fountain Publishers, IDRC |isbn=978-0-74532-625-2 |page=116 |archive-date=16 September 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130916062855/http://www.idrc.ca/EN/Resources/Publications/Pages/IDRCBookDetails.aspx?PublicationID=131 |url-status=dead }} Indeed, in one anthropological study conducted through on-the-ground research in Rwanda, both Hutus and Tutsis interviewed noted he was famous for his strong oratory skills. Prior to the genocide, Habimana took a more moderate line on racial issues than most adherents of [[Hutu Power]]. In December 1993, for example, Habimana stated the following while on air:
"Not all Tutsis are wicked; some of them are wicked. Not all Hutus are good, some of them are wicked. Of the ethnic groups, there are some wicked... This shows that human nature remains the same among all the ethnic groups in Rwanda, among all the men in Rwanda. But what type of person got it into his head that the RTLM hates the Tutsis?"{{Cite web|title=ICTR, The Media Case {{!}} How does law protect in war? – Online casebook|url=https://casebook.icrc.org/case-study/ictr-media-case|access-date=2021-04-12|website=casebook.icrc.org}}
However, during the genocide, Habimana routinely announced exact whereabouts, names and license plate numbers of alleged [[Rwandan Patriotic Front|RPF]] accomplices,{{cite journal |last1=Cotton |first1=Cassandra |year=2007 |title='Where Radio is King:' Rwanda's Hate Radio and the Lessons Learned. |journal=Atlantic International Studies Journal |pages=4–11 |url=http://atlismta.org/online-journals/0607-journal-gender-environment-and-human-rights/where-radio-is-king/#_ftn43 |access-date=17 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207011053/http://atlismta.org/online-journals/0607-journal-gender-environment-and-human-rights/where-radio-is-king/#_ftn43 |archive-date=7 February 2013 |url-status=dead }}[http://www.rwandafile.com/rtlm/pdf/rtlm0002.pdf Official UN transcript; ICTR-99-52-T; P103/2B, pg.4][http://www.rwandafile.com/rtlm/pdf/rtlm0122x.pdf Official UN transcript; ICTR-99-52-T; P103/122, pg.1] inciting targeted violence and often murder on the named individuals by groups such as the [[Impuzamugambi]] and [[Interahamwe]] militias. Habimana gave advice to listeners on how to identify Tutsis, saying that an individual's height and physical appearance can determine if they're Tutsi. Habimana instructed listeners to "[l]ook at the person's height and his physical appearance... Just look at his small nose and then break it”.{{Cite web|title=Three Media Leaders convicted for Genocide {{!}} United Nations International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda|url=https://unictr.irmct.org/en/news/three-media-leaders-convicted-genocide|access-date=2021-04-12|website=unictr.irmct.org}} == Life post-genocide and reported death == At a pre-genocide court hearing on March 15, 1994, for "the incitement of citizens against each other", Habimana would claim that RTLM broadcasters were "small fish" compared to RTLM executives such as [[Ferdinand Nahimana]], and thus bore little responsibility for the genocide.The Prosecutor v. Ferdinand Nahimana, Jean-Bosco Barayagwiza, Hassan Ngeze (Judgement and Sentence), ICTR-99-52-T, pg. 176, International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda (ICTR), 3 December 2003, available at: http://www.refworld.org/docid/404468bc2.html [accessed 21 December 2017] Habimana reportedly died of [[AIDS]] in the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]] sometime between 1998 and 2002.{{cite journal |last1=Li |first1=Darryl |year=2004 |title=Echoes of violence: Considerations on radio and genocide in Rwanda. |journal=Journal of Genocide Research |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=25 |doi= 10.1080/1462352042000194683|s2cid=85504804 |url=https://www.academia.edu/362149 |access-date=19 March 2013}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Ig-22hF5Rg&t=1m10s A recording of Kantano Habimana on-air on RTLM (starts at 1:10).] * [http://www.rwandafile.com/rtlm/index.html RwandaFile: Transcripts of RTLM broadcasts, including numerous by Kantano Habimana] {{Radio Télévision Libre des Mille Collines}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Habimana, Kantano}} [[Category:Rwandan radio presenters]] [[Category:Rwandan people convicted of genocide]] [[Category:Rwandan propagandists]] [[Category:Radio controversies]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:Deaths from AIDS-related illness]] [[Category:20th-century births]]

Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's [[Help:Using talk pages|talk page]] or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''redirect to [[Miss Venezuela 2010#Official contestants]]'''. '''[[User:MBisanz|MBisanz]]''' [[User talk:MBisanz|talk]] 21:37, 13 April 2013 (UTC) ===[[Andrea Escobar]]=== :{{la|Andrea Escobar}} – ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Andrea Escobar|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2013 April 2#{{anchorencode:Andrea Escobar}}|View log]]{{int:dot-separator}} [http://toolserver.org/~snottywong/cgi-bin/votecounter.cgi?page=Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/Andrea_Escobar Stats]) :({{Find sources|Andrea Escobar}}) This stub article has a surprisingly complicated history. It used to be a poorly referenced stub on a Miss Venezuela contestant ({{Revision link|405607556|this revision}}) but was [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Andrea_Escobar&diff=429574472&oldid=405607556 redirected two years ago] to the Miss Venezuela 2010 article. A year later, the redirect was replaced by another poorly referenced biography of a beauty pageant participant with the same name but from Colombia. The problem is basically the same: complete lack of significant third-party coverage. The Colombian Andrea Escobar also landed an acting gig in a telenovela but despite the claim of the article, IMDb appears to indicate that it's a non-recurring minor part. So what do we do with this mess? One option is to revert to the redirect to Miss Venezuela 2010 since we at least have a redirect target. (We do not have an article for the pageant in which the Colombian Andrea Escobar participated) A second option is to just delete because it's quite unlikely that readers will actively search for a non-notable contestant in a 2010 Venezuelan pageant or for an equally non-notable Colombian model/actress. In some sense, deletion is fair to these two women: we just declare them equally non-notable. The last option, of course, is to create separate articles for the two Andrea Escobars and turn the current article into a disambiguation page. I think deletion is the best of the three options. [[User:Pichpich|Pichpich]] ([[User talk:Pichpich|talk]]) 20:37, 19 March 2013 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Colombia|list of Colombia-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|• Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 14:58, 20 March 2013 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Fashion|list of Fashion-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|• Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 14:58, 20 March 2013 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Actors and filmmakers|list of Actors and filmmakers-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|• Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 14:58, 20 March 2013 (UTC) * '''Delete''' - I agree with the nominator that in this case, declaring both equally non-notable is probably for the best. Plus, the title that the original Andreas held was Miss Yaracuy, which does not have an article of its own. [[User:Mabalu|Mabalu]] ([[User talk:Mabalu|talk]]) 15:41, 20 March 2013 (UTC)
:'''[[WP:RELIST|Relisted]] to generate a more thorough discussion so a clearer consensus may be reached.'''
:Please add new comments below this notice. Thanks, —'''[[User:Theopolisme|Theopolisme]] ([[User talk:Theopolisme|talk]])''' 00:19, 26 March 2013 (UTC)
:'''[[WP:RELIST|Relisted]] to generate a more thorough discussion so a clearer consensus may be reached.'''
:Please add new comments below this notice. Thanks, [[User:Mediran|'''Mediran''']] ([[User talk:Mediran|'''t''']] • [[Special:Contributions/Mediran|c]]) 02:55, 2 April 2013 (UTC)
*'''Restore Redirect''' - The second Escobar does not appear to have particpated in a major beauty pageant nor does her acting career indicate any notability. The first Escobar competed in a major beauty pageant in the form of [[Miss Venezuela]]. A redirect to the entrants for 2010 was appropriate then, and remains appropriate now. -- [[User:Whpq|Whpq]] ([[User talk:Whpq|talk]]) 17:09, 5 April 2013 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's [[Help:Using talk pages|talk page]] or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.''

revision.comment: Say what she campaigned for, not against
revision.text:
{{Short description|British mental health campaigner (1854–1946)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use British English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ida Darwin | image = | caption = | birth_date = 7 November 1854 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1946|7|5|1854|11|7|df=y}} | spouse = [[Sir Horace Darwin]] | children = [[Erasmus Darwin IV]]
[[Ruth Frances Darwin]]
[[Nora Barlow]] | parents = }} '''Ida, Lady Darwin''' (née '''Farrer'''; 7 November 1854 – 5 July 1946) was the wife of [[Sir Horace Darwin]], member of the [[Ladies Dining Society]], and a co-founder in 1913 of the Central Association for the Care of the Mentally Defective (in 1921 renamed the Central Association for Mental Welfare). Darwin was born '''Emma Cecilia Farrer''' and took the name Ida from [[Hans Christian Andersen]]’s fairy tale of ''Little Ida's Flowers''. Her father was Permanent Secretary to the Board of Trade [[Thomas Farrer, 1st Baron Farrer|Thomas Farrer]] and her mother was Frances Erskine, daughter of the historian and orientalist [[William Erskine (historian)|William Erskine]] and granddaughter of [[Sir James Mackintosh]]. Thomas Farrer was a friend of [[Charles Darwin]] and, following the death of Frances Farrer, married Katherine Wedgwood, niece of [[Emma Darwin]].[https://www.surreycc.gov.uk/culture-and-leisure/history-centre/marvels/a-visit-to-mr-darwin Surrey History Centre: A visit to Mr Darwin], surreyccgov.uk. Accessed 5 October 2023. On 3 January 1880, she married her stepmother's cousin, Sir [[Horace Darwin]], youngest son of Charles and Emma Darwin, at [[St Mary's, Bryanston Square]].Births, Deaths, Marriages and Obituaries. Freeman's Journal and Daily Commercial Advertiser (Dublin, Ireland), Thursday, 8 January 1880. The couple had a son and two daughters:Burke's Landed Gentry, Darwin formerly of Downe. * [[Erasmus Darwin IV]] (7 December 1881 – 24 April 1915) who was killed in the [[Second Battle of Ypres]] during the [[First World War]].[http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/1609108 CWGC:: Casualty Details], cwgc.org. Accessed 5 October 2023. * [[Ruth Darwin|Ruth Frances Darwin]] (1883–1972) who was an advocate of [[eugenics]] and married Dr [[William Rees-Thomas]]. * [[Nora Barlow|Emma Nora Darwin]] (1885–1989) who edited the 1959 edition of ''[[The Autobiography of Charles Darwin]]'' and married the civil servant Sir [[Alan Barlow]]. Ida and Horace Darwin settled in Cambridge, where they lived at "The Orchards", a 24-room mansion on Huntingdon Road. A full complement of servants gave Darwin the leisure to pursue activities outside the home. In 1883 she was a founding member of the Cambridge Association for the Care of Girls, an organisation that identified working-class girls who were deemed to be wayward or out of control and placed them in domestic service or sent them to training institutions for service, and that also ran recreational clubs for girls.{{cite book |last=Rixon |first=Andy |editor-last=Robb |editor-first=M |title=Youth in Context: Frameworks, Settings and Encounters |publisher=Sage Publications |date=2007 |pages=13–52 |chapter=Chapter 1: Practitioners}} She later joined the [[Ladies Dining Society]]. Darwin was also on the committee of the Cambridge [[Charity Organization Society#Britain's Charity Organisation Society|Charity Organisation Society]] and in 1908, in response to the recommendations of Royal Commission for the Care and Control of the [[feeble-minded|Feeble-Minded]], together with [[Florence Ada Keynes]] formed a sub-committee to enquire into the number of "defective" children in Borough schools.{{cite book |last=Woodcock |first=John |date=c. 1983 |title=75 Years of Voluntary Endeavour: a review of the work of the Cambridgeshire Mental Welfare Association 1908-1983}} This sub-committee became the Cambridge Association for the Care of the Feeble-Minded and members included the Mayor of Cambridge, the [[Regius Professor of Physic (Cambridge)|Regius Professor of Medicine]] and representatives from the Borough Education Committee, the Eastern Counties Asylum in Colchester and the Cambridge Association for the Care of Girls. The group campaigned for the passage of legislation that would put the recommendations of the Royal Commission into force and organised meetings and conferences. In 1912 the Association, jointly with Cambridge University Eugenics Society, held a meeting in the Guildhall, where [[Ellen Pinsent]] read a paper on ''Mental Defect and its Social Dangers''.{{cite book |last1=Blackman |first1=Elsie |last2=Rootham |first2=Rosamund|date=1951 |title=Notes on the history of Cambridgeshire Mental Welfare Association}} After the [[Mental Deficiency Act 1913|Mental Deficiency Act]] was passed in 1913 the Association merged with the Cambridgeshire Voluntary Association for the Care of the Mentally Defective, which had just been formed by the County Council. This organisation was affiliated to the Central Association for the Care of the Mentally Defective (later the Central Association for Mental Welfare). Darwin was a vice-president of the Central Association for Mental Welfare and as such was a signatory to a letter to ''[[The Times]]'' in 1929 calling for the segregation and supervision of existing defectives and an inquiry into the causes of mental deficiency:
"Since its formation in 1914 the Central Association for Mental Welfare has on numerous occasion drawn public attention to the social problem presented by mental deficiency and to the grave consequences and serious cost entailed by the presence of mental defectives in the community".''The Times'', 22 July 1929, p. 29.
Although Darwin reduced her public commitments following the death of her son in 1915, she maintained links with the Central Association for Mental Welfare until the end of her life.''The Times'', Saturday, 6 July 1946; p. 7; Issue 50496; col E. Darwin died on 5 July 1946, aged 91, and is buried in Cambridge at the [[Parish of the Ascension Burial Ground, Cambridge|Parish of the Ascension Burial Ground]], along with her husband. She had an obituary in ''The Times'', with a further note by [[Leslie Scott (UK politician)|Leslie Scott]][[Leslie Scott (UK politician)|Leslie Scott]] KC Hon. Lady Darwin. Obituaries, ''The Times'', Tuesday, 16 July 1946; pg. 7; Issue 50504; col E. who described her as "one of the pioneers in this country in the field of social work". The [[Fulbourn Hospital#Ida Darwin Hospital|Ida Darwin Hospital]], built in the 1960s on the Fulbourn Hospital site, was named in her honour. She also has an iris, Mrs Horace Darwin, named after her. == References == {{Farrer family tree}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Darwin, Ida}} [[Category:1854 births]] [[Category:1946 deaths]] [[Category:Daughters of barons]] [[Category:Wives of knights]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Place of death missing]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Iconathon_Image.png|right|frame|The Wikimedia Foundation Iconathon]]
The Wikimedia Foundation is partnering with [http://www.thenounproject.com The Noun Project] to do a public service "Iconathon." The goal of this event is to generate 30-40 icons for the public domain, with the intent of primarily using them on Wikimedia Foundation projects. The event is open to the public in an effort to bring talented designers and civic-minded individuals into the process. The event will be held on April 6, 2013 at the Wikimedia Foundation headquarters in San Francisco ([http://goo.gl/maps/xG0lS map]), and will last from 10:30AM to 4:30PM PST.
All icons will be released under a public domain license.
== Why? ==
The primary goal of building new icons is to help solidify the visual identity of the various projects of the Wikimedia Foundation and to bring consistency across the user interface.
Rather than using another freely available icon set, we are building our own icon package because:
* Existing free icon sets are insufficient: ** They often contain icons that are crudely or inconsistently designed; ** They often contain a mix of styles, having been accreted over time ** They often contain archaic symbology (e.g., a floppy disk for "save") ** They are often incomplete for our purposes; ** They are often designed for operating systems rather than singular applications; ** They are often designed to mimic other icon sets; ** Individual icons have often been repurposed ad infinitum, thus diluting the symbolic meaning of any individual icon; * We are a top-five property, and should have our own visual identity; * We have multiple teams working on multiple projects. A shared icon set will help us avoid "style drift".
== How Can I Help? ==
You can help in several ways!
* Come to the iconathon! We very much would like it if members of the Wikimedia movement community would attend. If you're anywhere near the Bay Area, stop by and help out. Even if you don't feel that you have the skills to create icons, you can be a valuable asset by helping us understand possible problems with selected imagery. * Leave comments on the talk page. ** Suggest additional icons ** Suggest ideas on how to visualize the icons in our list ** Point out some possible problems with specific icons that may arise in cross-language or cross-cultural situations * If you've an artistic or design bend, create sketches and share them with us. We are working like this: determine need -> idea -> sketch -> finalize.
== Event Structure ==
The event will be structured as follows: # A WMF staff member will give a presentation to illustrate the specific iconography problems faced on Wikipedia and its sister projects. # A co-founder of The Noun Project will give a presentation explaining the overall design process and sequence of events. # Teams of 3-5 people will be formed, with each team including at least one designer. # The teams will sketch and whiteboard concepts for icons assigned to them. # The finalized sketches will be collected by The Noun Project.
The Noun Project will be responsible for collecting the finalized icon sketches and rendering them as vector images. They will be published roughly one month after the event as CC-licensed images without a specific owner.
== Icon List ==
The list of icons to be created is below. These have been broken out into broad categories. Some icons must be done in sets, or are intended to be part of a larger library.
=== Article Status === * Article is Reviewed * Article is Nominated for Deletion * Article is Unreviewed * Protected from Editing (6 levels) *: This icon will be a "set" icon. It is intended as a suggestion to the Wikimedia community as a replacement for the existing protection icons (which can be confusing given that the only differential is color) * Rapidly Changing Article * Featured Article *: Another suggestion. This is intended to be an exploration into quality descriptors.
=== Process === * Edit Reverted / Rolledback * Oversight * Request Oversight * Undo Oversight
=== Users and Rights === These icons describe different kinds of users. * Administrator * Anonymous User * Blocked User * Bot
=== System Chrome === * Feed / Flow * Font Settings (Languages) * Contributions
=== Education === These icons are intended to be illustrative of the [[WP:5|Five Pillars]]. It is highly likely that they will not be able to stand on their own as visual symbols as the concepts themselves are esoteric.
* Encyclopedia Worthy * Neutral Point of View * No Original Research * Original Work * Verifiability
=== Other === * Save Page for Offline Reading * Thank You, Gratitude * User Feedback
=== Low Priority === These icons may be interesting to create or brainstorm about but may have limited use or viability.
* Citation Needed * New Article * Wiki Love Symbol/ Gratitude
== Relevant links == * [http://blog.wikimedia.org/2013/03/13/the-noun-project-and-the-wikimedia-foundation-host-an-iconathon-to-create-an-encyclopedia-collection-of-free-icons/ Blog post announcing the event] * [http://blog.wikimedia.org/2013/05/03/wikimedia-iconathon-update/ Blog update post regarding the Iconathon] * [http://thenounproject.com/ The Noun Project]

revision.text:
'''Martin Galling''' (born 1935 in [[Halle (Saale)]]) is a German pianist, harpsichordist and chamber musician.
Galling first took cello lessons and studied the piano from 1945 at the [[Peter Cornelius Conservatory]] of [[Mainz]] with Louise Wandel. He studied at the [[Hochschule für Musik Mainz]], counterpoint with [[Günter Raphael]], and chamber music and musicology with [[Günter Kehr]]. In 1956 he was in the master class of [[Hans Leygraf]], followed by concerts in Germany and tours of Western Europe, the U.S., Israel and Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bach-cantatas.com/Bio/Galling-Martin.htm|title=Martin Galling (Harpsichord, Piano)|publisher=Bach Cantatas|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> Galling was a soloist on numerous tours of the [[Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra]] under [[Karl Münchinger]], and collaborated with [[Helmuth Rilling]]. From 1970 to 2000 he was a professor of chamber music at the [[Hochschule für Musik Saar]] (Music Academy of the Saarland). In 2003 he founded the piano duo Galling-Olivieri.
Galling recorded the complete [[harpsichord]] music of Bach for a series of six three-LP sets released on the [[Vox Records|Vox]] label (repackaged in 1970 as an 18-disc set by Murray Hill Records). The series contains all of Bach's major, and many minor, pieces, with the exception of some youthful productions (preludes, fugues, sonatas, and the like), and also does not include a [[harpsichord]] rendition of ''[[The Art of Fugue]]''. For this recording, Galling used a "revival" instrument, a modern [[harpsichord]] with stops not found on [[harpsichords]] modeled on ancient instruments, including a 16-foot stop (one octave below the two 8-foot stops) and a lute stop which was probably not modeled on the same stop found on ancient instruments. This recording of the complete harpsichord works of Bach is currently (2017) available as a vinyl rip in the form of Mp3 files on Amazon.com.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.arkivmusic.com/classical/Name/Martin-Galling/Performer/25652-2 Recordings]
{{Authority control}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2014}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox album | name = Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe | type = studio | artist = [[Buffalocomotive]] | cover = Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe - Album Cover.jpg | border = yes | alt = A black-and-white photograph of a zeppelin exploding | released = {{Start date|2012|08|27}} | recorded = December 2005 – September 2011, Side Saddle Studios, [[Joliet, Illinois]] | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Hard rock]] | length = {{Duration|m=47|s=23}} | language = English | label = | producer = [[Buffalocomotive]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Singles | name = Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe | type = studio | single1 = [[MedHed]] | single1date = 2012 }} }} '''''Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe''''' is the debut album by the American [[Hard rock]] band [[Buffalocomotive]], released worldwide via [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon MP3]] on August 27, 2012.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150208034557/https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/tears-enchanted-mainframe/id556698202 Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe released August 27, 2012 on iTunes]. iTunes. Retrieved on 2012-08-30.</ref><ref>[http://amzn.com/B0093DNDY0 Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe released August 27, 2012 on Amazon.com]. Amazon.com. Retrieved on 2012-08-30.</ref> Buffalocomotive recorded the album in Chicago, Illinois and [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] between December 2005 and January 2012, with most of the recording conducted via telecommuting. The album established Buffalocomotive's desire to fuse heavy instrumentation with melodic vocals and cerebral lyrics that are both fantasy/science fiction-focused as well as being indicative of the human experience.
==Background== In 2005 drummer Scott Carneghi reunited with guitarist Marc Kaducak and bassist, vocalist Brahm Taylor, after several previous collaborations, to begin work on their debut effort. Taylor wrote new songs for the project and repurposed older material from his earlier tenure with Kaducak. The month before releasing ''Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe'' Kaducak suggested a re-branding and Taylor changed the band's name to Buffalocomotive.
==Recording and production==
===Recording sessions=== The recording of the album commenced in December 2005 with the drum tracks for "Superusurper" and "MedHed" and concluded with a [[shaker (musical instrument)|shaker]] track for "Tremendous And Wide" in January 2012.
All of the drum and guitar tracks were recorded at a private facility dubbed "Side Saddle Studios" in [[Joliet, Illinois]] with the majority of bass and vocal tracks being recorded remotely by Taylor in Las Vegas.
For the recordings, Kaducak played a 70's era [[Gibson (guitar company)|Gibson]] ES-335TD, a 1993 [[Gibson Les Paul]] Studio, a 2007 [[Gibson SG]] Standard, and a 1985 G&L Cavalier along with [[Randall Amplifiers]] and a [[Marshall Stack]]. He also used a [[Takamine Guitars|Takamine]] 12-string for the album's acoustic tracks. Kaducaks guitars were recorded with SM57's through a Randall 4x12 cabinet with Celestion Vintage 30 speakers. Taylor recorded with a [[Rickenbacker 4003]] amplified through an [[Ampeg SVT]] with the majority of the album's bass sound being derived from a direct signal being processed through a [[Tech 21]] SansAmp. Taylor's vocals were captured with an [[Audio-Technica]] AT4050 mic. Carneghi utilized several different [[DW Drums|DW]] drum kit configurations with [[Paiste]] Cymbals. His drums were captured using Shure Beta 52A on the kick, Shure SM57 on the snare, Sennheiser E604 on the toms and a pair of Oktava MC-012's on the overheads. A Royer R121 Ribbon was used to record the ambiance of the room during drum takes.
During the recording process drums and guitars went through a variety of preamps including a [[Rupert Neve Designs]] Portico 5012, an ART MPA tube preamp and the Steinberg MR816 preamps/audio interface. Analog to digital conversions were achieved through Steinberg, and in some cases Mytek, converters.
The album was recorded and mixed exclusively with Steinberg [[Cubase]] digital audio workstations on Microsoft windows operating systems with Waves SSL and Abbey Road TG12413 plugins. It was revealed that neither Brahm nor Marc know how to operate [[Autotune]], so it was not used.
The songs were often performed to a [[click track]], but there was no "snapping the drums to a grid", which is a popular computerized technique to ensure that drums are in perfect time while simultaneously sucking the life out of an otherwise real performance.
===Production=== ''Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe'' was produced and engineered by Taylor and Kaducak.
[[Backmasking]] is used on the track "[[Superusurper]]" during an interlude that features a reversed reading of a passage from the [[George Orwell]] novel Nineteen eighty four.
The album was [[Audio mastering|mastered]] by Geoff Pesche and Alex Wharton at [[Abbey Road Studios]] in London.
==Title and artwork== ''Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe'' was an original title purportedly chosen to evoke the mental imagery of late 1960s science fiction novels.
[[Image:Buffalocomotive Concept Art.jpg|thumb]] The album cover depicts a faceless android with right hand raised in benediction, donning flowing [[kasaya (clothing)|kasaya]] and [[war bonnet]] against a [[Nimbus (art)|nimbus]] of [[blinkenlights]].<ref name="Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe">[http://s.pixogs.com/image/R-3828548-1346010371-2357.jpeg Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe album cover]. Discogs.com. Retrieved on February 4, 2013.</ref> The portrait's artistic style and typography emulates a series of [[Philip K. Dick]] novels published by [[DAW Books]] in the early 1980s.<ref name="A Scanner Darkly">[http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/51HZnLrl1RL.jpg A Scanner Darkly]. Amazon.com. Retrieved on February 4, 2013.</ref>
A loose Native American motif can be derived from the band's name (Buffalocomotive), the character depicted on the album cover (nicknamed "Geronimotor") and the album title in [[acronym]] form ([[totem]]).
The original idea for the cover involved a photograph of a young girl in funeral attire indulging in a tray of chocolate cupcakes each topped with a different esoteric symbol in white icing.
==Music and lyrics== To create interest through contrast, Buffalocomotive utilizes musical shifts in song dynamics, going from quiet to loud and vice versa, often placing gentler material against more aggressive fare. All Buffalocomotive songs are performed with the guitars tuned down one whole step from [[standard tuning]] with some tracks featuring an additional [[drop D tuning]].
The lyrics of the song "Mint Green" [[personify]] [[paper money]] as an [[absolute monarch]] and use different shades of green, including emerald, [[forest green|forest]] and [[mint green|mint]], as a metaphor for USD. An analogy is drawn between greed and [[opioid dependence]] early in the song.
Lyrically the song "Often The Orphan" draws comparisons to the uncanny frequency in which orphaned protagonists are featured in folklore, literature and film.
"Tremendous And Wide" was intended as a lament for victims of [[Fundamentalism]], [[plastic shaman]]ism and general [[magical thinking]].
==Reception== {{Album reviews | rev1 = Sputnikmusic |rev1Score = {{Rating|3|4}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/55490/Buffalocomotive-Tears-Of-The-Enchanted-Mainframe/ |title=Sputnikmusic Review |publisher=Sputnikmusic.com |date=March 4, 2013 |accessdate=March 5, 2013}}</ref> | rev2 = [[SNSPost]] |rev2Score = {{Rating|4|5}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.snspost.com/buffalocomotive-tears-of-the-enchanted-mainframe/ |title=SNSPost Review |publisher=SNSPost.com |date=October 3, 2012 |accessdate=March 5, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028071811/http://www.snspost.com/buffalocomotive-tears-of-the-enchanted-mainframe/ |archivedate=October 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> }} In the United States the album received a positive review in the SNSPost where [[Kevin Abud]] wrote, in a review titled "Buffalocomotive: Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe": "Tears of the Enchanted Mainframe is a masterful effort. Thirteen songs as powerful as the name of the band. Not since the likes of Sabbath have I heard anything with the kind of gusto and creative punches that can slap you in the face 13 times in a row".<ref name="SNSpost">[http://www.snspost.com/buffalocomotive-tears-of-the-enchanted-mainframe/ Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe review] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028071811/http://www.snspost.com/buffalocomotive-tears-of-the-enchanted-mainframe/ |date=October 28, 2012 }}. SNSPost.com. Retrieved on October 4, 2012.</ref>
[[Hernan M. Campbell]] of Sputnik Music said "I highly recommend this album to anyone looking for a quality and straightforward hard rock album" and "the music is proficient and orchestrated in an impactive fashion that fully entertains until the final second".<ref name="Sputnik Music">[https://www.sputnikmusic.com/review/55490/Buffalocomotive-Tears-Of-The-Enchanted-Mainframe/ Tears Of The Enchanted Mainframe review]. SputnikMusic.com. Retrieved on October 4, 2012.</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = George S. Wise | image = George S. Wise (990044328640205171) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Wise, 1969 | native_name = ג'ורג' וייז | birth_name = George Schneiweis | birth_date = April 6, 1906 | birth_place = [[Pinsk]], [[Belorussia|White Russia]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_date = July 2, 1987 | death_place = [[Miami Beach, Florida]], U.S. | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | native_name_lang = he | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = [[Furman University]]
[[Columbia University]] | employer = | occupation = Sociologist | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = Florence Rosenberg | children = | parents = | relatives = }} [[File:GeorgeWise1875.JPG|thumb|alt=Bust of George S. Wise at Tel Aviv University|Bust of George S. Wise at Tel Aviv University]] '''George Schneiweis Wise''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: ג'ורג' וייז; April 6, 1906 – July 2, 1987) was an American sociologist who served as the first president of [[Tel Aviv University]] in [[Ramat Aviv]], [[Israel]] from 1963 to 1971.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/03/obituaries/george-s-wise-dead-led-tel-aviv-university.html|title=George S. Wise Dead; Led Tel Aviv University|date=July 3, 1987|work=The New York Times|accessdate=19 March 2013}} ==Early life== George Schneiweis (later Wise) was born in [[Pinsk]], [[Belorussia|White Russia]], [[Russian Empire]] in 1906. He emigrated to the United States in 1926.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oQ9XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O0MNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1073,434291&dq=george-wise&hl=en|title=George Wise, noted educator, industrialist, dies in Miami|last=Moore|first=Marilyn A.|date=July 2, 1987|work=[[The Miami News]]|page=27|accessdate=19 March 2013|archive-date=21 January 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200121205915/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oQ9XAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O0MNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1073,434291&dq=george-wise&hl=en|url-status=dead}} He graduated from [[Furman University]] in 1928 and got his advanced studies at [[Columbia University]]. ==Career == Wise taught Sociology at Columbia in 1930, a post he held until 1952. He became internationally known as an expert in Latin American and Israeli affairs, with a particular focus on [[caudillo]] dictatorships that were common in Latin American politics at the time. In 1951 he wrote a biography of [[Antonio Guzmán Blanco]], the former dictator of [[Venezuela]] which was published by [[Columbia University Press]].{{cite news|title=Strong Men Like Money|last=Bracker|first=Milton|date=December 2, 1951|work=The New York Times|id = {{ProQuest|112080405}}}}{{subscription required}} A known [[Zionist]], he was chairman of the board for the [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]. In 1951, he was named president of the [[American Friends of the Hebrew University]] of Jerusalem.{{cite web|url=http://archive.jta.org/article/1951/10/29/3029643/george-s-wise-to-head-american-friends-of-hebrew-university|title=George S. Wise to Head American Friends of Hebrew University|date=October 29, 1951|publisher=Jewish Telegraphic Agency|accessdate=19 March 2013|archive-date=5 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205090356/http://www.jta.org/1951/10/29/archive/george-s-wise-to-head-american-friends-of-hebrew-university|url-status=dead}} In 1953, he was elected the head of the Hebrew University Board of Governors. As head, Wise led a major expansion program of the University, and still held the honor of "chancellor for life" at the time of his death. He became the first president of Tel Aviv University in 1963, serving as such until 1971, when he was succeeded by [[Yuval Ne'eman]].{{cite web|author=Basch_Interactive |url=https://english.tau.ac.il/list_of_presidents |title=Presidents of Tel Aviv University | Tel Aviv University | Tel Aviv University |publisher=English.tau.ac.il |date=1980-01-01 |accessdate=2020-02-11}} Wise was also director of the Center for Advanced International Studies and a member of the board of governors for the [[University of Miami]]. Wise was the owner of George S. Wise and Co. and the Inter-American Paper Corp., both newsprint manufacturers. According to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', he built the "first [[newsprint]] plant" in Mexico.{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1987-07-04-mn-121-story.html|title=George S. Wise; 1st President of Israeli School|date=July 4, 1987|work=Los Angeles Times|agency=Associated Press|access-date=19 March 2013}} ==Philanthropy== As a philanthropist, Wise worked on fighting illiteracy in Mexico by founding 30 schools, which led the Mexican government to honor Wise with the [[Order of the Aztec Eagle]], the highest award given to a foreigner in 1949. ==Personal life, death, and legacy== Wise married Florence Rosenberg, who died on January 11, 2013, at the age of a hundred.{{cite web|url=http://www.aftau.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17825|title=In Memoriam: Florence Rosenberg Wise|date=January 15, 2013|publisher=American Friends of Tel Aviv University|accessdate=19 March 2013|archive-date=20 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130320124912/http://www.aftau.org/site/News2?page=NewsArticle&id=17825|url-status=dead}} He died in [[Miami Beach, Florida]], on July 2, 1987, after suffering from heart failure for several months. Upon hearing of his death, former Prime Minister of Israel [[Menachem Begin]] described Wise as "the dearest man I ever met". The [[Wise Observatory]] and the George S. Wise Faculty of Life Sciences at Tel Aviv University is named after Wise. == References == {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wise, George Schneiweis}} [[Category:1906 births]] [[Category:1987 deaths]] [[Category:American sociologists]] [[Category:Belarusian Jews]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:Israeli sociologists]] [[Category:Jewish sociologists]] [[Category:Literacy and society theorists]] [[Category:Academic staff of Tel Aviv University]] [[Category:Presidents of universities in Israel]] [[Category:Soviet emigrants to the United States]]

page.title: Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/You, Me, and Us (band)

revision.text: :''The following discussion is an archived debate of the proposed deletion of the article below. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's [[Help:Using talk pages|talk page]] or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.'' The result was '''delete'''. [[User:J04n|J04n]]([[User talk:J04n|talk page]]) 00:41, 26 March 2013 (UTC) ===[[You, Me, and Us (band)]]=== :{{la|You, Me, and Us (band)}} – ([[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/You, Me, and Us (band)|View AfD]][[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2013 March 19#{{anchorencode:You, Me, and Us (band)}}|View log]]{{int:dot-separator}} [http://toolserver.org/~snottywong/cgi-bin/votecounter.cgi?page=Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/You,_Me,_and_Us_(band) Stats]) :({{Find sources|You, Me, and Us (band)}}) Fails [[WP:MUSIC|notability for bands and music]], no suggestion anywhere of why this may be appropriate for Wikipedia. ([[User talk:Bwilkins|✉→]]'''[[User:Bwilkins|BWilkins]]'''[[Special:Contributions/Bwilkins|←✎]]) 20:49, 19 March 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete'''. There's a paragraph-long album review in the band's [http://www.free-times.com/index.php?cat=11011801074507906&ShowArticle_ID=11012708081010676 local newspaper] but that's well short of meeting [[WP:GNG]] and [[WP:BAND]]. Elsewhere on Google I'm seeing mentions on their own Facebook/ReverbNation/Bandcamp/etc pages and that's about it. [[User:Gongshow|''' Gong ''']][[User_talk:Gongshow|'''show''']] 21:24, 19 March 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''' The subject fails [[WP:BAND]], which is why it was PRODed to begin with. §[[User:FreeRangeFrog|FreeRangeFrog]][[User talk:FreeRangeFrog|croak]] 21:56, 19 March 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''', not notable per [[WP:MUSIC]]. [[User:NawlinWiki|NawlinWiki]] ([[User talk:NawlinWiki|talk]]) 22:01, 19 March 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''' per everyone. What's more, the links make me wonder if they're attempting to promote themselves through this article. [[User:Nyttend|Nyttend]] ([[User talk:Nyttend|talk]]) 00:49, 20 March 2013 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/South Carolina|list of South Carolina-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|• Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 15:23, 20 March 2013 (UTC) :Note: This debate has been included in the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Deletion sorting/Bands and musicians|list of Bands and musicians-related deletion discussions]]. [[User:Gene93k|• Gene93k]] ([[User talk:Gene93k|talk]]) 15:23, 20 March 2013 (UTC) *'''Delete''' with objection to userfying - Not only is the article untidy, multiple detailed Google News searches only provided three more local news articles [http://www.free-times.com/index.php?cat=1992912064160665&ShowArticle_ID=11012104092194656 here], [http://www.free-times.com/index.php?ShowArticle_ID=11012302093598049&cat=1992912064160665 here] and [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CS&s_site=thestate&p_multi=CS&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=12122F5C9BC32D80&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM here] (all for events). I have no objection to userfying or a future article when they are notable. [[User:SwisterTwister|SwisterTwister]] [[User talk:SwisterTwister|talk]] 19:36, 20 March 2013 (UTC) :''The above discussion is preserved as an archive of the debate. '''Please do not modify it.''' Subsequent comments should be made on the appropriate discussion page (such as the article's [[Help:Using talk pages|talk page]] or in a [[Wikipedia:Deletion review|deletion review]]). No further edits should be made to this page.''

__TOC__ {{SPIarchive notice|1=Sumitpramanik007}} {{SPIpriorcases}} =====17 March 2013===== ;Suspected sockpuppets * {{checkuser|1=14.139.223.98}} *[http://toolserver.org/~betacommand/cgi-bin/uc?uc=Sumitpramanik007 User compare report] ''Auto-generated every hour.'' *[http://toolserver.org/~snottywong/editorinteract.html Editor interaction utility] This user created an (auto)biographical article at [[:Sumit Kumar Pramanik]]. After an autobiographical notice to the user and autobio/notability tags on the article, the tags were removed repeatedly by the IP ([[http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sumit_Kumar_Pramanik&diff=544650731&oldid=544626335]] first removal). Repeated removal and reinstatement escalated to final warning ([http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk%3A14.139.223.98&diff=544896005&oldid=544895398 userpage diff]) at which point the main user reappeared to remove the tags: [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Sumit_Kumar_Pramanik&diff=544897438&oldid=544895921 diff]. The IP is registered to Indian Institute of Chemical Biology which is where the user works [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Sumitpramanik007]; this is clearly a tag-team operation of signed-in and signed-out accounts to act against normal article maintenance tagging. __TOC__ {{SPIarchive notice|1=Ashumech527}} {{SPIpriorcases}} =====18 March 2013===== ;Suspected sockpuppets * {{checkuser|1=Ashutoshmech527}} *[http://toolserver.org/~betacommand/cgi-bin/uc?uc=Ashumech527 User compare report] ''Auto-generated every hour.'' *[http://toolserver.org/~snottywong/editorinteract.html Editor interaction utility] Names almost the same, identical edits at [[Bhumihar]] [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&curid=16454727&diff=545221332&oldid=545220033] and [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&diff=545183443&oldid=545182968]. [[User:Dougweller|Dougweller]] ([[User talk:Dougweller|talk]]) 16:10, 18 March 2013 (UTC) ======Comments by other users====== ''Accused parties may also comment/discuss in this section below. See [[Wikipedia:Sockpuppet investigations/SPI/Guidance#Defending yourself against claims|Defending yourself against claims]].'' ======Clerk, CheckUser, and/or patrolling admin comments====== *{{cudecline}} Clearly related to the other account, no edits since the report. [[User:Keegan|Keegan]] ([[User talk:Keegan|talk]]) 04:05, 19 March 2013 (UTC) ---- =====24 June 2014===== ;Suspected sockpuppets * {{checkuser|1=Bhumihar brahmin}} * {{checkuser|1=Alexnews}} * {{checkuser|1=Bpandey89}} *[http://tools.wmflabs.org/betacommand-dev/cgi-bin/uc?uc=Ashumech527 User compare report] ''Auto-generated every hour.'' *[http://tools.wmflabs.org/sigma/editorinteract.py Editor interaction utility] Based on a report at [[WP:AN3]], I blocked the master account for 31 hours for edit warring at [[Bhumihar]]. After the block, the puppet (not a new account), came along and made similar edits as the master. Master ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&diff=614030887&oldid=614021120]; puppet [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&diff=614255474&oldid=614252503]. I blocked the puppet for 72 hours for edit warring, but thus far have not amended the block of the master. The CU is requested not only for these two accounts but also for sleepers as there are quite a few strange edits to the same article. However, those edits may simply be driven by many editors with ethnic biases as opposed to the same individual. Finally, as the two listed accounts, there is little behavioral evidence to go on because neither of them ''talks'' much, either on article or user talk pages.--[[User:Bbb23|Bbb23]] ([[User talk:Bbb23|talk]]) 23:41, 24 June 2014 (UTC) [[User:Bbb23|Bbb23]] ([[User talk:Bbb23|talk]]) 23:41, 24 June 2014 (UTC) ======Comments by other users====== ''Accused parties may also comment/discuss in this section below. See [[Wikipedia:Sockpuppet investigations/SPI/Guidance#Defending yourself against claims|Defending yourself against claims]].'' Something is clearly going on here as a 3rd editor, Alexnews, arrived with the same edits. I've added him but in this case the language[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&diff=614338188&oldid=614336342] is more or less identical of that of Bhumihar brahmin.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Bhumihar&diff=614269927&oldid=614266714] [[User:Dougweller|Dougweller]] ([[User talk:Dougweller|talk]]) 10:19, 25 June 2014 (UTC) :Yep. I've just added Bpandey89. They haven't edited the article but they are effectively taking the same line as the other two but doing so on user talk pages, eg: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk%3ASitush&diff=614390678&oldid=614363173 here] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:MelbourneStar&diff=prev&oldid=614392927 here]. Why they aren't raising it at the article talk page is beyond me but I'll point them in that direction, and also to [[WP:DEADLINE]] and [[WP:CENSORED]]. However, I am now wondering whether this is more a meatpuppet situation, which is quite common for caste-related articles because the communities co-ordinate off-wiki using [[Orkut]] and similar. - [[User:Sitush|Sitush]] ([[User talk:Sitush|talk]]) 17:44, 25 June 2014 (UTC) ======Clerk, CheckUser, and/or patrolling admin comments====== * {{confirmed}} for the first two, but Bpandey89 is {{inconclusive}} even though they geolocate from the same region in India. — [[User:Coren|Coren]] [[User Talk:Coren|(talk)]] 04:01, 29 June 2014 (UTC) *CU confirmed accounts blocked indef and tagged along with the master. No action on Bpandey89. Closing. [[User:Callanecc|Callanecc]] ([[User talk:Callanecc|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Callanecc|contribs]] • [[Special:Log/Callanecc|logs]]) 08:00, 29 June 2014 (UTC) ----
